ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Thinking about linguistic anthropology through various thinkers and using linguistic anthropology to understand new fields like technology
survey of key works in linguistic anthropology, how to analyze anthropology research

learned a lot about the way different scholars approach linguistics. the first few weeks felt very theoretical as we reviewed the work of some famous linguists. after that we got into some more "applicable" and culture-based readings. learned a lot about language indexicality and developed a stronger linguistic vocabulary

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Professor was really clear and organized in linking concepts from different weeks
I thought the course went at a good pace and I enjoyed the readings, I do wish there was more of a discussion component though

strengths: prof kockelman is very intelligent and the course material is very interesting if you actually read and engage with it (if you're genuinely interested in linguistics). workload isn't too bad. just weekly reading responses and a final paper. 

weaknesses: the content can be very dense. while prof k unpacks things quite well, it takes a few weeks to adjust to the content of the course as well as his style of speaking/teaching. prof k is very smart, but sometimes his language is very convoluted and hard for me to follow.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes. For someone without any background in linguistics or anthropology, I learnt a lot at a very short time. Steep learning curve but manageable!

if you have some linguistic or anthropological background and are genuinely interested in SCHOLARLY work in those fields, then yes. if this is your first time with either field, be prepared to adjust for the first few weeks of class.
